image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Vastrapur Village
image.Description: RLV: The line between 'home' and 'public space' and 'place' is not as clear in these rural communities at the time of the photo. Probably not much has changed but would be curious what this area looked like today. At the time of these photos, RLV described his initial interest was really focused on the public space being a 'studio' to build pots for a local festival in which people would purchase pots to 'throw down and break during a celebration' only to be recycled again for a future use/celebration. The pots he noted were well made, almost perfect in symmetry despite the hand held and crude tools used to spin the pots. The artisan stacked the pots on end creating 'racks' of pots that overtook the public space of this small settlement. The importance of art and decorative elements in everyday life in the poorest of communities never ceased to fascinate RLV from India, to China, to Spain or Cambodia. Capturing the culture of each place he visited was as important as the buildings in that most of the time one informed the other and could be found in the details of the art, the buildings and their design.

image.Title: Frederick Douglass School
image.Description: RLV: The entire school was broken down into a series of balanced parts off of a central 'green' with an 'art room' that extends out from the orderly plan.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor); VMDO Architects (Charlottesville, Va.) (American architectural firm, 1976 CE-)
image.Title: Frederick Douglass School
image.Description: RLV: The walkway is lined now with trees and is a pedestrian pathway from the fields and parking lots below. It leads into the school's central green and the art classroom. At the time of the development, this feature was unusual for a public school. The campus pays attention to the grade of the land to create maximum use of the elevations and access to classrooms varying by the age of the students.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Schoffner, C.
image.Creator: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor); VMDO Architects (Charlottesville, Va.) (American architectural firm, 1976 CE-)
image.Title: Frederick Douglass School

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor); VMDO Architects (Charlottesville, Va.) (American architectural firm, 1976 CE-)
image.Title: Frederick Douglass School

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor); VMDO Architects (Charlottesville, Va.) (American architectural firm, 1976 CE-)
image.Title: Frederick Douglass School
image.Description: RLV: The entryway to the school was based on a Palladian design where the door was not on center but on either sides of a central column. The entire school was broken down into a series of balanced parts off of a central 'green' with an 'art room' that extends out from the orderly plan. The library 'floats' above the entrance; the round windows signal at the entrance the special nature of the library function in education.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Vastrapur Village
image.Description: RLV: The line between 'home' and 'public space' and 'place' is not as clear in these rural communities at the time of the photo. Probably not much has changed but would be curious what this area looked like today. At the time of these photos, RLV described his initial interest was really focused on the public space being a 'studio' to build pots for a local festival in which people would purchase pots to 'throw down and break during a celebration' only to be recycled again for a future use/celebration. The pots he noted were well made, almost perfect in symmetry despite the hand held and crude tools used to spin the pots. The artisan stacked the pots on end creating 'racks' of pots that overtook the public space of this small settlement. The importance of art and decorative elements in everyday life in the poorest of communities never ceased to fascinate RLV from India, to China, to Spain or Cambodia. Capturing the culture of each place he visited was as important as the buildings in that most of the time one informed the other and could be found in the details of the art, the buildings and their design.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor); VMDO Architects (Charlottesville, Va.) (American architectural firm, 1976 CE-)
image.Title: Frederick Douglass School
image.Description: RLV: The entryway to the school was based on a Palladian design where the door was not on center but on either sides of a central column. The entire school was broken down into a series of balanced parts off of a central 'green' with an 'art room' that extends out from the orderly plan. The library 'floats' above the entrance; the round windows signal at the entrance the special nature of the library function in education.

image.Title: Scottsville Elementary School
image.Image_View_Description: corridor model, spherical library visible at lower left
image.Description: RLV: Can a corridor connect the old school with a new school concept without too much of a programmatic change for the user and the client? The corridor was a prevailing theme for Vickery's work.

image.Title: Scottsville Elementary School
image.Description: RLV: Interior walkway separates the original classrooms on the left from the new, spherical red tile library on the right (which was visible from the outside front).

image.Title: Red Hill Elementary School
image.Image_View_Description: main entry through portal and canopy
image.Location: North Garden, Albemarle, Virginia, United States
image.Description: RLV: Original school to the left was torn down and inside the open terrace at center is a meeting area/dining room that is accessed underneath the blue metal canopy with yellow awning. The library slanted roof is storage and utilities area and provides additional light. Preliminary scheme done by R. L. Vickery.

image.Title: Broadus Wood Elementary School
image.Description: RLV: Details of different colors of brick and 'reveal' or indentations in specific places that only the trained eye might see were a hallmark of Vickery's specifications as part of his overall plans. They were sometimes pragmatic and sometimes only decorative.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Rodia, Simon (American sculptor and folk artist, 1879-1965)
image.Title: Watts Towers
image.Location: Watts, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, California, United States
image.Artstor_Classification: Sculpture and Installations|Architecture and City Planning|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: This was taken when Robert Vickery and his wife were preparing for their trip around the world. This was one of the most dangerous places in the United States and in Los Angeles, which still suffers from poverty and crime, and was constructed by a mailman, not a trained artist. He built these towers from the trash from others with no pragmatic use but symbolic in an area that had little hope. That art exists despite the troubles all around the artist and his community.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Rodia, Simon (American sculptor and folk artist, 1879-1965)

He built these towers from the trash from others with no pragmatic use but symbolic in an area that had little hope. That art exists despite the troubles all around the artist and his community.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Rodia, Simon (American sculptor and folk artist, 1879-1965)
image.Title: Watts Towers
image.Location: Watts, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, California, United States

image.Title: Chapman House
image.Description: RLV: focus on breaking down large spaces into smaller liveable spaces that extend into the landscape and provide the best possible view from a number of rooms. Creating a space both wanted and needed by the client, five children and a grandmother. Can you see the influences of Frank Lloyd Wright?

image.Title: Cross Penthouse
image.Description: RLV: The challenge in high rise living is to put all the main rooms in one sequence from the entry hall, living room, and dining area and beyond. Linear grouping of spaces delineated by the columns (not necessarily for structural purposes) and ornamental mantel connecting the columns with a pass through above. The columns were faux finished and were purchased from an older building - at the time a fairly new design approach.

image.Title: Woodberry Forest School
image.Description: RLV: This is the Woodberry Forest study room and entry area shared by two dormitories. It explored a concept that an interior could change from space to space largely through the treatment of decorative versus structural elements with glass and two story open atria.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Alcázar of Segovia | Segovia Castle
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: The castle began as a fortification for the neighborhood nearby donated by the Catholic Church. Then it later became a castle for a home for the king. It was built 'on the rock' and is more intact because this particular property is closer to Madrid and was incorporated into the military and is a repository for royal library and art collections.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)

image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: The castle began as a fortification for the neighborhood nearby donated by the Catholic Church. Then it later became a castle for a home for the king. It was built 'on the rock' and is more intact because this particular property is closer to Madrid and was incorporated into the military and is a repository for royal library and art collections.

image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Aqueduct, Segovia, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: In a city that has a series of massive monumental architecture works, the practical application of the aqueduct stands in stark contrast to decorative beauty of the cathedral and the fortification design of Alcazar. The diverse community built in between of vernacular housing has been done with great care and guidance by UNESCO and other overriding historical designations.

image.Title: New Castle of Manzanares el Real | Castle of los Mendoza
image.Location: Manzanares, Ciudad Real, Castilla-La Mancha, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: This castle was unique because of its square formation and the influence of the 'mudejar' architecture and completion by an architect influenced by the Castilian culture, French and Flemish. The Moorish elements appear in the detailing and speak to a mixing of Moorish culture where the Christian influence dominated.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: New Castle of Manzanares el Real | Castle of los Mendoza
image.Location: Manzanares, Ciudad Real, Castilla-La Mancha, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: This castle was unique because of its square formation and the influence of the 'mudejar' architecture and completion by an architect influenced by the Castilian culture, French and Flemish. The Moorish elements appear in the detailing and speak to a mixing of Moorish culture where the Christian influence dominated. The stone decorations are quite significant and detailed along the roof line.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Great Mosque of Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: The Great Mosque used western elements in its design which were considered innovative. The use of the arches and how groupings work together to support the overall design continued to influence some of the design aesthetic of later years.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Great Mosque of Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: The use of two patterns of arches supported by a series of columns created an unusual flow of space and shadows above and spatial references for the person walking through what would be a very large room that reads more intimately.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Great Mosque of Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: A more well lit photo of the Great Mosque hallway of intersecting archways and columns.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Great Mosque of Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Ornamental tiling detailing history and stories might have influenced eventual use of tiling design, color and placement to describe pathways and use of different buildings.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Great Mosque of Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Example of how a square plan can read like a hexagon and integrate previous patterns of arches found below. Intricate use of tiling in complementary geometric shapes in the spaces found between the layers leading to the top.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Great Mosque of Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: A culminating pattern of intersecting geometry at the peak of the hexagon.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Street tree and pavement, Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: An ancient drainage plan that still works in modern society. Raised sidewalk with patterns of water flow to planted trees in the public square.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Courtyard, Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: This courtyard exemplifies the design of the period with the secluded space and an arcade above with arches that are delicate and ornate.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Church of San Pablo, Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: A pre-existing church and adjoining more modern structure share a courtyard.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Great Mosque of Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: As compared to previous Romanesque church style, the mosque entryway is somewhat more delicate columns, ornate treatment of thinner walls.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Hermitage of the Conception, Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: Plaza de Abades; built 1750| RLV: A later built church begins to combine elements found in the mosques of the area (much like the Great Mosque of earlier era incorporated elements of traditional historic churches) in a tribute to a Catholic icon.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Pedestrian street showing arched braces, Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Elements of design that would define the public space in more intimate sections through the special use and placement of arches (both structurally and aesthetically placed) and doorways with lighting and plantings.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Pedestrian street, Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Simple colors at second floor balconies and street level windows and doorways create interest between one side of a street and the other.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Pedestrian street, Cordoba, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Simplicity of design for urban villages was key for a farming and pre-industrial society (no cars were around then!) called for detailing by 'color' and draining rain down the middle of the street so bikes and people could walk on either side.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Courtyard of the Lions, Alhambra, Granada, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: The lions were very pure design for a fountain with water flow in four directions; double support columns integrated with single column placement.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Courtyard of the Lions, Alhambra, Granada, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Another view of the Lion Fountain Courtyard from the perspective of inside and looking at the patterns of two and single columns with very sparse gardening elements.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Courtyard of the Lions, Alhambra, Granada, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: The lack of competing gardening elements provide a clean backdrop for the lion fountain and the ornate columns and detailing around the courtyard. In newer photos, it appears the sand is lighter than this photo from the 1960s.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Courtyard of the Lions, Alhambra, Granada, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs

image.Title: Parc Güell
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: These curves are built with hand-colored tiles. A tower of Sagrada Famila appears in the background.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Gaudí, Antoni (Spanish architect, landscape architect, and furniture designer, 1852-1926)
image.Title: Parc Güell
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Gaudí followed the organic curves of nature building in curves and circles into many of the seats and has tiles made by local craftsman, vividly colored in mosaics throughout the park.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Gaudí, Antoni (Spanish architect, landscape architect, and furniture designer, 1852-1926)
image.Title: Parc Güell
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Tiled seat in the park; repairs visible on the right. Symbolism is that it doesn't seem to go with the rest of the park sculpture, and yet it does.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Gaudí, Antoni (Spanish architect, landscape architect, and furniture designer, 1852-1926)
image.Title: Parc Güell
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Gaudí, Antoni (Spanish architect, landscape architect, and furniture designer, 1852-1926)
image.Title: Parc Güell
image.Image_View_Description: retaining wall under the park, showing walkway
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Gaudí took the side of the hill and molded a park; down below the wall has been slanted to restrain the force of the park above and create a curvilinear walkway.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Gaudí, Antoni (Spanish architect, landscape architect, and furniture designer, 1852-1926)
image.Title: Parc Güell
image.Image_View_Description: retaining wall under the park, showing sculpture
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Gaudí used the images of women holding up the wall on the other side of the curvilinear walkway.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Gaudí, Antoni (Spanish architect, landscape architect, and furniture designer, 1852-1926)
image.Title: Parc Güell
image.Image_View_Description: tiled drainage tunnel designed by Gaudí
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Gaudí built into the park various drainage tunnels that fed a series of small ponds at key points with the use of sculpture of playful animals.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Gaudí, Antoni (Spanish architect, landscape architect, and furniture designer, 1852-1926)
image.Title: Parc Güell
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Gaudí used the interpretation of the coconut as a naturalistic feature sculpture and to direct the path to walk around the park under the tree lined area.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)

image.Title: Palacio Güell | Casa Güell
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Rooftop treatments to a series of apartments completed by Gaudí. His designs were playful in opposition to the strident fascism of the government at the time. He tested his designs to withstand the weather.

image.Title: Sagrada Familia
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: When Vickery first saw the building he was impressed with the structural elements, curves and trusting the power of architecture emphasis on anti-Spanish, fantasy-driven design for a traditional building of a church. In 2004, he continued to be drawn to the message of growing upward and moving upward not captured similarly by any other example of landmark building in such a way.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Belém Tower, Portugal
image.Location: Belém, Lisbon, Lisboa, Distrito de, Portugal
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: This fortification guards the entry to Lisbon and was the place where the King would greet returning ships. The roof/plaza was used by soldiers who could manage the heavy guns should enemy ships also come near the coastline. The Manueline architecture is a complex combination of many different styles including decorative figures that celebrate the national accomplishments of the Portuguese explorers.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Belém Tower, Portugal
image.Location: Belém, Lisbon, Lisboa, Distrito de, Portugal
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: This fortification guards the entry to Lisbon and was the place where the King would greet returning ships. The roof/plaza was used by soldiers who could manage the heavy guns should enemy ships also come near the coastline. The Manueline architecture is a complex combination of many different styles including decorative figures that celebrate the national accomplishments of the Portuguese explorers.

The Manueline architecture is a complex combination of many different styles including decorative figures that celebrate the national accomplishments of the Portuguese explorers. This photo was taken as Vickery researched that the return by Vasco de Gama to the tower was an important moment in Portuguese history.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land

image.Title: Bom Jesus do Monte
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: This church of a later era displays a beautiful fountain and cascading stairwell design. The designer of the staircase was a combination of rococo and neoclassical design elements. The Staircase of the Theological Virtues was conceived by Carlos Amarante. The idea of moving through time and space was a modern notion and the staircase is exemplary of that change in approach to the church - as opposed to simply moving in a straight line into a building and drawn to a final destination. The process of getting to the destination was as much of importance as the arriving at the front door of the church.
image.Subjects: religious complexes; pilgrimage centers; Baroque; stairs; Roman Catholicism

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Ellis, Harvey (American architect, painter, designer, 1852-1904)
image.Title: Washington Terrace Gate
image.Location: Saint Louis, Saint Louis City, Missouri, United States
image.Description: RLV: This type of gated community was built when the surrounding Washington University campus didn't yet exist except for a few buildings in a cornfield. There was a boom in industrial development and the houses were quite large for the era. The 1904 Louisiana Purchase Exposition world's fair occurred about the time the neighborhood was finished. The private street is a way of living - can it be used today in modern urban society? How would it change?

image.Description: RLV: This photograph shows the integration of light and materials of the architect; his use of thin columns created both frames and patterns in the most unusual ways. The quality of the light is exceptional given that this landmark building is in a snowy area most of the year.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Neighborhood street, Monsaraz, Portugal
image.Description: RLV: In the rural towns, the people made the best of what they could with simple design and no sidewalks. In this photo a large rock was left to be part of the building interface with the street. The chimneys too were adorned with some ornamentation.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Stone building, Monsaraz, Portugal
image.Description: RLV: Vickery likes the way this photo shows the craftsmanship of the rock-laying to create a facade and install white washed details around the windows and doors.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Neighborhood street, Monsaraz, Portugal
image.Description: RLV: This photo shows the number of ways the craftsman stacked rocks to create streets, houses and interface of stairwells off the streets and drainage down the middle.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: House, Monsaraz, Portugal

image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Parish Church of Monsaraz|Igreja de Nossa Senhora da Lagoa
image.Description: RLV: This photo shows the amount of lavish craftsmanship and wealth spent on the decorative elements of the church chapel in a town with simple housing and infrastructure.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Buçaco Forest|Mata Nacional do Buçaco
image.Description: ... an ancient, walled arboretum in the Centro region of Portugal and home to one of the finest dendrological collections in Europe. ... Buçaco Forest was first settled in the 6th century by friars from a nearby Benedictine monastery; five hundred years later the Bishops of Coimbra took possession of the forest and in 1628 donated it to the Order of Discalced Carmelites. ... In 2004 Portugal submitted Buçaco Forest to UNESCO's tentative list of World Heritage Sites. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bu%C3%A7aco_Forest

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Roman Temple of Évora|Temple of Diana
image.Description: The temple is believed to have been constructed around the first century A.D., in honour of Augustus, who was venerated as a god during and after his rule. ... The temple was destroyed during the 5th century by invading Germanic peoples. ... Although the Roman temple of Évora is often called the Temple of Diana, any association with the Roman goddess of hunt stems not from archaeology but from a legend created in the 17th century by [a] Portuguese priest. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Temple_of_%C3%89vora

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Roman Temple of Évora|Temple of Diana
image.Description: The temple is believed to have been constructed around the first century A.D., in honour of Augustus, who was venerated as a god during and after his rule. ... The temple was destroyed during the 5th century by invading Germanic peoples. ... Although the Roman temple of Évora is often called the Temple of Diana, any association with the Roman goddess of hunt stems not from archaeology but from a legend created in the 17th century by [a] Portuguese priest. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Temple_of_%C3%89vora

image.Title: Dom Luís I Bridge over the Douro River, Porto, Portugal

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Aqueduct, Segovia, Spain
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: In a city that has a series of massive monumental architecture works, the practical application of the aqueduct stands in stark contrast to decorative beauty of the cathedral and the fortification design of Alcazar. The diverse community built in between of vernacular housing has been done with great care and guidance by UNESCO and other overriding historical designations.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Alcázar of Segovia | Segovia Castle
image.Description: RLV: The castle began as a fortification for the neighborhood nearby donated by the Catholic Church. Then it later became a castle for a home for the king. It was built 'on the rock' and is more intact because this particular property is closer to Madrid and was incorporated into the military and is a repository for royal library and art collections.

image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Galician hórreo
image.Description: RLV: Hórreo is a centuries old style of building a storage unit primarily practice in northern Spain to protect new crops from rodents. It's a vernacular style that persists today and has even been used as an option for a small dwelling unit.

image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Gerona, Spain riverfront
image.Description: RLV: Gerona is an example of middle class dwelling units along the waterway when in 1960's they would use the balconies to dry their laundry. At the time the photo was taken, one couldn't drive into the city but enter it through pedestrian bridge pathways. A spectacular church is a focal point, one of the largest single naves of Catholic church in Spain.

image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Campo del Moro
image.Location: Madrid, Madrid, Comunidad de Madrid, Spain
image.Description: Campo del Moro (the "Field of the Moor") is the huge urban park located directly behind the Palacio Real in Madrid Spain. Once a private playground for the Royal family, Campo del Moro today is popular destination for residents and visitors to Madrid. It features English style gardens, fountains, statues and natural woodlands. It dates back to Moorish times and was more recently the royal hunting grounds. -- https://espanarusa.com/en/hedonist/ad/hedonist/categories/Soul/city_park/497686
image.Subjects: parks (grounds); parks (recreation areas); fountains; cultural landscapes

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land

image.Title: Palacio Güell | Casa Güell
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Rooftop treatments to a series of apartments completed by Gaudí. His designs were playful in opposition to the strident fascism of the government at the time. He tested his designs to withstand the weather.

image.Title: Piazza Castello, Marostica, Italy
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: In the second week end of September in the even-numbered year, a game of chess using live pieces is played. After the First World War, members of the local chess club began playing chess in the main square and decided to play a game of chess using people as the gamepieces. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marostica

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Chiesa di San Pietro Caveoso, Chiesa di Santa Maria di Idris, and city walls, Sassi di Matera, Italy
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: RLV: Intrigued by the building of homes into hillside and rock, and the culture of the people who lived so ruggedly in the mountains, the series of photos of the 'Sassi' show just how impoverished the community was in the 60s. Interestingly, the location has become in 2018 a cultural 'hot spot' for young travelers and a UNESCO protected site as well. | The Sassi originate from a prehistoric troglodyte settlement and are suspected to be among the first human settlements in Italy. There is evidence that people were living here as early as the year 7000 BC. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sassi_di_Matera
image.Subjects: churches (buildings); religious buildings; caves; townscapes (built environment)

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Bargello | Bargello Palace | Museo Nazionale del Bargello | Palazzo del Popolo | Palace of the People
image.Description: Originally the building was the headquarters of the Capitano del Popolo (Captain of the People) and later of the Podestà. Later, in the sixteenth century, it became the residence of the Bargello (the head of the police) and was used as prison during the entire 18th century. In the 1865, the building became a museum.
image.Subjects: palaces; official residences; prisons; museums; courtyards

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Santa Maria Novella
image.Description: RLV: Santa Maria Novella is the most noted example of Alberti's work because he used all the configurations on one surface - geometric balance, intricate tile details as well as a strict graphic stone patterns. The interior is as well studied because of the continued use of strict graphic stone patterns and the exquisite paintings that began to explore 3-d and perspective in the representations of biblical content. Alberti had a history of working with visual artists as part of his architectural programs.

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Navicella Fountain, Minor Basilica of St. Mary in Domnica alla Navicella | Fontana della Navicella
image.Description: The fountain was built in 1931 using the small marble vessel which was already here, built in 1518-19, possibly based on a drawing by Andrea Sansovino, on the orders of Poe Leo X Medici (whose coat of arms is on the base). The small vessel, a Roman galley, is inspired by the ancient vessel discovered in the vicinity of the Colosseum, according to legend, an offering to the goddess Isis, the protector of seafarers, made by some sailors who had escaped disaster. Remembered here in the fifteenth century, the vessel also gives its name to the church of Santa Maria in Domnica, or alla Navicella. In its current position, with the bow in the form an animal head, it is placed on a base inside an oval basin, in a flowerbed. -- http://www.leviedelgiubileo.it/?p=5058
image.Subjects: fountains; hydraulic structures; sculpture (visual work); galleys (watercraft); arcades (structural assemblies)

image.Collection: Robert Vickery: Marks Upon the Land
image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Trulli and rural landscape
image.Artstor_Classification: Architecture and City Planning|Garden and Landscape|Photographs
image.Description: A trullo (plural, trulli) is a traditional Apulian dry stone hut with a conical roof. Their style of construction is specific to the Itria Valley, in the Murge area of the Italian region of Apulia. Trulli generally were constructed as temporary field shelters and storehouses or, as permanent dwellings by small proprietors or agricultural labourers. In the town of Alberobello, in the province of Bari, whole districts contain dense concentrations of trulli. The golden age of trulli was the nineteenth century, especially its final decades, which were marked by the development of wine growing. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trullo|| RLV: Vickery was drawn to this village because of the roof construction done without an architect or engineer at a time when there was no mortar available. He appreciated a roof line without an arch, that wasn't flat and was completely unique and repeated as homes for peasants originally and have survived for centuries.

image.Title: Château de Villandry
image.Description: The château dates from the 16th century; the Renaissance gardens date from the early 20th century and include a water garden, ornamental flower gardens, and vegetable gardens. image.Subjects: country houses; formal gardens; Renaissance Revival; parterres

image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Title: Archway, La Couvertoirade, France
image.Description: This well-preserved fortified town was owned by the Knights Templar, under orders from the Commandery of Sainte-Eulalie, from the twelfth century. The Templars built the fortress there during the 12th and 13th centuries .... Following their dissolution in 1312, the Templars' property in the causses was taken by the Knights of St John of Jerusalem who were responsible for building the curtain wall at La Couvertoirade between 1439 and 1450. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Couvertoirade

image.Photographer: Vickery, Robert L. (American architect and university professor)
image.Creator: Peichl, Gustav (Austrian architect, born 1928)
image.Title: Bank Austria Kunstforum Vienna
image.Description: The neoclassical building was built from 1914 to 1921 to designs by the architects Ernst Gotthilf and Alexander Neumann as a bank building for the Austrian Creditanstalt für Handel und Gewerbe. Architect Gustav Peichl was commissioned to rebuild the Kunstforum in 1988 and [it] reopened in March 1989. Soon after, the new owner, Bank Austria, renamed the facility to Bank Austria Kunstforum. From late 1992 to early 1993 was rebuilt again and doubled the exhibition space. -- https://de.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_Austria_Kunstforum_Wien (translated)
image.Subjects: art galleries; art museums; Secession Movement; Art Nouveau; banks (financial institutions); adaptive reuse

image.Description: formerly the church of the Augustinian monastery (convent) of St. Elisabeth. Initial construction 13th century; enlarged and renovated throughout 15th century; secularized and renovated for various purposes beginning in 1529. Converted to a theater, 1802. -- https://www.landestheater-schwaben.de/geschichte-stadttheater-memmingen.html (translated)
image.Subjects: churches (buildings); religious buildings; convents (nunneries); theaters (buildings); adaptive reuse

image.Title: Expo 67
image.Location: Montreal, Montréal, Île de, Quebec, Canada
image.Description: The Biosphere (French: "La Biosphère de Montréal") is a museum dedicated to the environment. ... in the former pavilion of the United States for the 1967 World Fair, Expo 67. ... In August 1990, Environment Canada purchased the site for $17.5 million to turn it into an interactive museum showcasing and exploring the water ecosystems of the Great Lakes-Saint Lawrence River regions. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montreal_Biosphere
image.Subjects: Expo (International Exhibitions Bureau) (1967 : Montréal, Québec); world's fairs; geodesic domes; Fuller, R. Buckminster (Richard Buckminster), 1895-1983

image.Title: School of Architecture Annual Regatta and Picnic, June 1973, University of Virginia
image.Location: Rivanna Reservoir, Albemarle, Virginia, United States
image.Description: The School of Architecture's Annual Regatta and Picnic started in 1972 with inspiration from Professor H. Kenneth White. White assigned his studio the project of designing cardboard boats that would be able to be propelled across the Rivanna Reservoir. In subsequent years, the regatta grew to be a school-wide event. (pp 63-64) -- https://issuu.com/uvaschoolofarchitecture/docs/aschoolhistory_1a757995fd80a6
image.Subjects: events; watercraft; University of Virginia. School of Architecture; boats
